sub_topic: Chemical reaction kinetics and rate equations
message_1: A chemical reaction follows the rate law,  $Rate = k[A]^2[B]$. If the concentration of reactant A is 0.01 M and the concentration of B is 0.02 M, and the rate constant k is 0.02 M^-1 s^-1, what is the rate of the reaction in M/s?
message_2:
To find the rate of the reaction, we can plug the given values into the rate law equation:

$Rate = k[A]^2[B]$

$Rate = (0.02\,\text{M}^{-1}\,\text{s}^{-1})(0.01\,\text{M})^2(0.02\,\text{M})$

$Rate = (0.02)(0.0001)(0.02)$

$Rate = 4 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{M/s}$

So the rate of the reaction is $4 \times 10^{-5}$ M/s.
